thread.title_full: Maple Leafs close out pre-season with fifth consecutive loss

title: Maple Leafs close out pre-season with fifth consecutive loss
text:
The Maple Leafs’ pre-season schedule couldn’t end soon enough. 
Thankfully, it’s done. 
The Leafs, after three consecutive wins to open the exhibition season, lost five in a row, the final setback coming to the tune of 2-1 against the Detroit Red Wings on Saturday night. 
Before a less-than-capacity crowd of 17,879 at the Air Canada Centre, the Leafs outshot the wings 29-15 but didn’t generate a bushel of great scoring opportunities. 
Jonathan Bernier, in his final audition to be the Leafs’ No. 1 goalie to open the regular season on Wednesday at the ACC against the Montreal Canadiens, looked ordinary on a goal by Andreas Athanasiou at 13:50 of the second period. Then again, the defence pair of Morgan Rielly and Roman Polak were of little help. 
Athanasiou burst between the two, with Polak barely glancing at him, and beat Bernier with a wrist shot that was stoppable. 
Detroit increased its lead to 2-0 at 19:06 of the second when Anthony Mantha scored a power-play goal as public address announcer Andy Frost was giving notice of a holding penalty to James van Riemsdyk. Mantha took a pass from Athanasiou and fired the puck over Bernier. 
Brad Boyes scored for the Leafs at 22 seconds of the third period, his goal coming on Toronto’s 22nd shot. The puck pinballed behind goalie Petr Mrazek before Boyes tapped it into the net. 
Coach Mike Babcock knew it would be a long road to get the Leafs back to respectability. With the pre-season done, and final cuts coming in the next day or two, he has a better grip on the fact little will come easy for this group. 
“What matters to me is we make the best decisions we possibly can,” Babcock said after the morning skate, referring to cuts. “We better know what we have before we get in a hurry to do something and then we find out later it was wrong. Being patient, I think, is important and we are going to do that.” 
terry.koshan@sunmedia.ca
